metadata.title: Preventive Suboccipital Decompressive Craniectomy for Cerebellar Infarction

hydrocephalus.sourceText: A unilateral EVD on the parieto-occipital point was usually set up before SDC for hydrocephalus and was performed in 14 (50.0%) patients in this study.

inclusionCriteria: (3) without clinical deterioration (no GCS score changes) within 72 hours from onset
(4) a cerebellar infarction volume ratio between 0.25 and 0.33 on initial or routine follow-up radiographic findings (within 72 hours of onset)

technique.value: Bilateral SDC with opening of the foramen magnum (even for unilateral infarction), extending margins to transverse and lateral sinuses. Dura opened in a large Y incision. Decompressive resection of infarcted cerebellum performed in 57.1% of patients.
technique.sourceText: Bilateral SDC with the opening of the foramen magnum was performed for all patients, even those with unilateral infarction. The upper and lateral margin of SDC extended as close as possible to the transverse and lateral sinuses. The dura was opened in a large Y incision. As the dura was opened and the infarcted brain began herniating outward, decompressive resection of the infarcted cerebellum was performed in 16 of 28 patients (57.1%).

evdUsed.sourceText: A unilateral EVD on the parieto-occipital point was usually set up before SDC for hydrocephalus and was performed in 14 (50.0%) patients in this study.

timingToSurgery.sourceText: Among them, 28 patients underwent preventive SDC with the following criteria: ... (3) without clinical deterioration (no GCS score changes) within 72 hours from onset; and (4) a cerebellar infarction volume ratio ... on initial or routine follow-up radiographic findings (within 72 hours of onset)

intervention.additionalDetails: Surgery performed in park-bench (three quarter) or prone position with head fixed in a three-pin fixator. Decompressive resection of the infarcted cerebellum was performed in 16 of 28 patients (57.1%).

comparator.description: Propensity score-matched control group of patients with cerebellar infarction who did not undergo preventive suboccipital decompressive craniectomy (SDC) but received best medical management.

mortality.value: Group A: 1 death; Group B: 5 deaths
mortality.sourceText: At discharge, 18 (64.3%) of the 28 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes with 1 death, whereas 27 (48.2%) of 56 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes with 5 deaths

mRS_favorable.sourceText: At the 12-month follow-up, 18 (66.7%) of the 27 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes, whereas 26 (51.0%) of the 51 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes

complications: Cerebrospinal fluid leakage requiring dura repair

allOutcomes.resultValue: Group A: 18 (64.3%) favorable; Group B: 27 (48.2%) favorable
allOutcomes.sourceText: At discharge, 18 (64.3%) of the 28 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes with 1 death, whereas 27 (48.2%) of 56 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes with 5 deaths

allOutcomes.resultValue: Group A: 18 (66.7%) favorable; Group B: 26 (51.0%) favorable
allOutcomes.sourceText: At the 12-month follow-up, 18 (66.7%) of the 27 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes, whereas 26 (51.0%) of the 51 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes

allOutcomes.resultValue: Group A: 1 death; Group B: 5 deaths
allOutcomes.sourceText: At discharge, 18 (64.3%) of the 28 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes with 1 death, whereas 27 (48.2%) of 56 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes with 5 deaths

allOutcomes.resultValue: Group B had more deaths than group A (P<0.05)
allOutcomes.sourceText: Group B had more deaths within 12 months than group A (log-rank, P<0.05).

allOutcomes.definition: Requiring additional surgery for dura repair
allOutcomes.sourceText: Procedure-related complications in group A occurred in 2 (7.1%) patients who underwent additional surgery for dura repair for cerebrospinal fluid leakage.

allOutcomes.resultValue: 5 patients (2 in group A and 3 in group B)
allOutcomes.sourceText: There were no complications related to recanalization procedures except for hemorrhagic transformation after recanalization in 5 patients (2 in group A and 3 in group B).

quality.selectionJustification:
S1 (0): The exposed cohort represents a selected group. While drawn from a database, the authors acknowledge selection bias where some eligible patients refused surgery or were not selected by surgeons, meaning it is not a truly representative consecutive series of all eligible patients.
S2 (1): The non-exposed cohort was drawn from the same prospectively collected database from the same 5 hospitals during the same time period.
S3 (1): Exposure (surgery) was ascertained from secure hospital medical records/database.
S4 (1): The study excluded patients with pre-existing disability (mRS ≥1) prior to the stroke, ensuring the outcome of interest (functional decline/poor outcome) was not present at baseline.
quality.comparabilityJustification:
C1 (1): The study controlled for GCS (the most important factor) via propensity score matching.
C2 (1): The study controlled for additional factors including Age, Sex, and NIHSS score through propensity score matching and multivariate logistic regression adjustment.
quality.outcomeJustification:
O1 (1): Outcome assessment was performed by independent investigators who were blinded to the study data.
O2 (1): Follow-up was 12 months, which is adequate for functional recovery assessment.
O3 (1): Follow-up rates were high (>90%) in the matched cohorts (27/28 in exposed, 51/56 in unexposed).
quality.biasNotes: The study is retrospective and subject to selection bias regarding who received the preventive surgery, which the authors acknowledge (S1=0). However, the use of propensity score matching, blinded outcome assessment, and high follow-up rates suggests a low risk of bias in other domains, resulting in a 'Good' quality rating overall.

metadata.title: Preventive Suboccipital Decompressive Craniectomy for Cerebellar Infarction

preOpMean.sourceText: without clinical deterioration (no GCS score changes) within 72 hours

hydrocephalus.sourceText: A unilateral EVD on the parieto-occipital point was usually set up before SDC for hydrocephalus and was performed in 14 (50.0%) patients in this study.

inclusionCriteria: without clinical deterioration (no GCS score changes) within 72 hours from onset
cerebellar infarction volume ratio between 0.25 and 0.33 on initial or routine follow-up radiographic findings

technique.value: Bilateral SDC with opening of the foramen magnum was performed for all patients regardless of infarction laterality, extending margins to the transverse and lateral sinuses. Decompressive resection of the infarcted cerebellum was performed in 57.1% of cases.
technique.sourceText: Bilateral SDC with the opening of the foramen magnum was performed for all patients, even those with unilateral infarction. The upper and lateral margin of SDC extended as close as possible to the transverse and lateral sinuses. ... decompressive resection of the infarcted cerebellum was performed in 16 of 28 patients (57.1%).

evdUsed.sourceText: A unilateral EVD on the parieto-occipital point was usually set up before SDC for hydrocephalus and was performed in 14 (50.0%) patients in this study.

duraplasty.sourceText: The dura was opened in a large Y incision. ... Duroplasty used an artificial dura.

timingToSurgery.sourceText: Among them, 28 patients underwent preventive SDC with the following criteria: ... (3) without clinical deterioration (no GCS score changes) within 72 hours from onset

intervention.additionalDetails: The procedure was performed with the patient in the park-bench (three quarter) or prone position, with the head fixed using a three-pin head fixator.

comparator.description: Propensity score-matched control group (Group B) consisting of patients with cerebellar infarction who did not undergo preventive suboccipital decompressive craniectomy (SDC) and received best medical management. The matching ratio was 1:2.

mortality.value: At discharge: 1 death (3.6%) in Group A vs 5 deaths (8.9%) in Group B; 12-month follow-up: Group B had more deaths than Group A (log-rank, P<0.05)
mortality.sourceText: At discharge, 18 (64.3%) of the 28 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes with 1 death, whereas 27 (48.2%) of 56 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes with 5 deaths (P=0.048)... Group B had more deaths within 12 months than group A (log-rank, P<0.05).

mRS_favorable.value: Group A: 66.7% vs Group B: 51.0% at 12-month follow-up (Definition: mRS 0-2)
mRS_favorable.sourceText: At the 12-month follow-up, 18 (66.7%) of the 27 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes, whereas 26 (51.0%) of the 51 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes... An mRS of 0 to 2 was defined as favorable

complications: Cerebrospinal fluid leakage requiring dura repair

allOutcomes.sourceText: At discharge, 18 (64.3%) of the 28 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes with 1 death, whereas 27 (48.2%) of 56 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes with 5 deaths
At the 12-month follow-up, 18 (66.7%) of the 27 patients in group A showed favorable outcomes, whereas 26 (51.0%) of the 51 patients in group B showed favorable outcomes

allOutcomes.resultValue: Group A: 1 death, Group B: 5 deaths
allOutcomes.sourceText: At discharge... with 1 death, whereas... with 5 deaths

allOutcomes.definition: Additional surgery for dura repair for cerebrospinal fluid leakage
allOutcomes.sourceText: Procedure-related complications in group A occurred in 2 (7.1%) patients who underwent additional surgery for dura repair for cerebrospinal fluid leakage.
Hemorrhagic transformation... Group A (n=28): 8 (28.6)... Group B (n=56): 15 (26.8)

quality.selectionJustification:
S1: 0 stars. The cohort is a selected group treated by a specific team of neurosurgeons (alumni of one institution), limiting representativeness.
S2: 1 star. Controls were drawn from the same prospectively collected database and time period as the cases.
S3: 1 star. Exposure was ascertained through review of medical records/surgical database.
S4: 1 star. Patients with pre-existing disability (mRS ≥1) were excluded, ensuring the outcome of interest (poor functional outcome) was not present at start.
quality.comparabilityJustification:
C1: 1 star. The study controlled for GCS (the most important factor) using propensity score matching.
C2: 1 star. The study controlled for Age (and other factors like NIHSS) via propensity score matching.
quality.outcomeJustification:
O1: 1 star. Outcome was assessed by independent investigators blinded to the study data.
O2: 1 star. Follow-up was 12 months, which is adequate for functional outcomes.
O3: 0 stars. A significant portion of the potential control pool (312/1102, 28%) was excluded due to lost follow-up before matching, introducing potential attrition bias.
quality.biasNotes: The study is rated Good (7 stars) but has notable limitations. There is selection bias due to the specific surgeon group (alumni of one institution). There is attrition bias in the control selection process, as 28% of eligible controls were excluded due to missing follow-up data. Additionally, the handling of deaths in the functional outcome analysis (mRS) is slightly ambiguous in the tables (n=27 for Group A vs n=28 total). Randomization was not possible, but Propensity Score Matching was used to mitigate confounding.
